title: 105_s2420
content: Establishment of National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine under Title IV of the Public Health Service Act, with a focus on the purpose of the center. The National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine conducts research, training, and health information dissemination on alternative treatments. It is headed by a director appointed by the Secretary and has an advisory council with at least half of the members being licensed practitioners. The National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine, headed by a director appointed by the Secretary, includes officio members representing major systems and individual consumers. The Director studies integrating alternative treatments with conventional medicine and ensures appropriate scientific expertise in research. The Director of the National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine incorporates expertise in research on complementary and alternative medicine into all funded research projects. They may establish review groups with scientific expertise and coordinate efforts with other Institutes and Federal agencies. The Director evaluates alternative and complementary medical treatments, diagnostics, and prevention modalities in various disciplines and systems. The Director of the National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine conducts or supports various research activities to ensure high-quality scientific review of alternative medical modalities. The Director also coordinates with specific personnel in each Institute for appropriate coordination and scientific input. Additionally, there is a data system and information clearinghouse in place. The Director of the National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine establishes a data system for worldwide research on alternative treatments and an information clearinghouse to disseminate knowledge. The Director of the Center supports the development of research centers for complementary and alternative medicine, which must meet specific requirements and include accredited facilities. The Director of the Center supports the establishment of independent research centers for complementary and alternative medicine, with support lasting up to 5 years and extendable based on peer review. Biennial reports on center activities are required. The Director of the Center submits biennial reports on activities to the Director of NIH. Resources, including facilities and fellowships, are ensured by the Director of NIH for the Center to carry out its duties effectively. Authorization of appropriations is also mentioned for this purpose. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine for fiscal years 1999 through 2003. Officers and employees from the Office of Alternative Medicine are transferred to the Center without affecting their status. The National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine is authorized appropriations for fiscal years 1999 through 2003. Funds and legal rights from the Office are transferred to the Center without affecting their availability or duties. Technical amendments are made to the Public Health Service Act to reflect the changes. The National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine is authorized appropriations for fiscal years 1999 through 2003. Amendments are made to the Public Health Service Act to reflect the changes in subsections.
